name: HttpServer
comment:
A server that delivers content, such as web pages, using the HTTP protocol.

The HttpServer is a dart-async.Stream that provides dart-io.HttpRequest objects. Each HttpRequest has an associated dart-io.HttpResponse object. The server responds to a request by writing to that HttpResponse object. The following example shows how to bind an HttpServer to an IPv6 dart-io.InternetAddress on port 80 (the standard port for HTTP servers) and how to listen for requests. Port 80 is the default HTTP port. However, on most systems accessing this requires super-user privileges. For local testing consider using a non-reserved port (1024 and above).

import 'dart:io';

main() {
  HttpServer
      .bind(InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V6, 80)
      .then((server) {
        server.listen((HttpRequest request) {
          request.response.write('Hello, world!');
          request.response.close();
        });
      });
}

Incomplete requests, in which all or part of the header is missing, are ignored, and no exceptions or HttpRequest objects are generated for them. Likewise, when writing to an HttpResponse, any dart-io.Socket exceptions are ignored and any future writes are ignored.

The HttpRequest exposes the request headers and provides the request body, if it exists, as a Stream of data. If the body is unread, it is drained when the server writes to the HttpResponse or closes it.

Bind with a secure HTTPS connection

Use dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure to create an HTTPS server.

The server presents a certificate to the client. In the following example, the certificate is named localhost_cert and comes from the database found in the pkcert directory.

import 'dart:io';
import "dart:isolate";

main() {
  var testPkcertDatabase = Platform.script.resolve('pkcert')
                                   .toFilePath();
  SecureSocket.initialize(database: testPkcertDatabase,
                          password: 'dartdart');

  HttpServer
      .bindSecure(InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V6,
                  443,
                  certificateName: 'localhost_cert')
      .then((server) {
        server.listen((HttpRequest request) {
          request.response.write('Hello, world!');
          request.response.close();
        });
      });
}

The certificate database is managed using the Mozilla certutil tool (see NSS Tools certutil). Dart uses the NSS library to handle SSL, and the Mozilla certutil must be used to manipulate the certificate database.

Connect to a server socket

You can use the listenOn constructor to attach an HTTP server to a dart-io.ServerSocket.

import 'dart:io';

main() {
  ServerSocket.bind(InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V6, 80)
    .then((serverSocket) {
      HttpServer httpserver = new HttpServer.listenOn(serverSocket);
      serverSocket.listen((Socket socket) {
        socket.write('Hello, client.');
      });
    });
}

Other resources

  • HttpServer is a Stream. Refer to the dart-async.Stream class for information about the streaming qualities of an HttpServer. Pausing the subscription of the stream, pauses at the OS level.

  • The http_server package on pub.dartlang.org contains a set of high-level classes that, together with this class, makes it easy to provide content through HTTP servers.

serverHeader.name: serverHeader
serverHeader.comment:
Set and get the default value of the Server header for all responses generated by this dart-io.HttpServer. By default, it's disabled.

If the serverHeader is set to null, no default Server header will be added to each response.

idleTimeout.name: idleTimeout
idleTimeout.comment:
Get or set the timeout used for idle keep-alive connections. If no further request is seen within dart-io.HttpServer.idleTimeout after the previous request was completed, the connection is dropped.

Default is 120 seconds.

Note that it may take up to 2 * idleTimeout before a idle connection is aborted.

To disable, set dart-io.HttpServer.idleTimeout to null.

sessionTimeout=.name: sessionTimeout=
sessionTimeout=.comment: Sets the timeout, in seconds, for sessions of this dart-io.HttpServer. The default timeout is 20 minutes.

port.name: port
port.comment: Returns the port that the server is listening on. This can be used to get the actual port used when a value of 0 for port is specified in the dart-io.HttpServer.bind or dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure call.

address.name: address
address.comment: Returns the address that the server is listening on. This can be used to get the actual address used, when the address is fetched by a lookup from a hostname.

listenOn.name: listenOn
listenOn.comment: Attaches the HTTP server to an existing dart-io.ServerSocket. When the dart-io.HttpServer is closed, the dart-io.HttpServer will just detach itself, closing current connections but not closing dart-io.HttpServer.HttpServer-listenOn.serverSocket.

bind.name: bind
bind.comment:
Starts listening for HTTP requests on the specified dart-io.HttpServer.bind.address and dart-io.HttpServer.bind.port.

The dart-io.HttpServer.bind.address can either be a dart-core.String or an dart-io.InternetAddress. If dart-io.HttpServer.bind.address is a dart-core.String, dart-io.HttpServer.bind will perform a dart-io.InternetAddress.lookup and use the first value in the list. To listen on the loopback adapter, which will allow only incoming connections from the local host, use the value [InternetAddress.LOOPBACK_IP_V4] or [InternetAddress.LOOPBACK_IP_V6]. To allow for incoming connection from the network use either one of the values [InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V4] or [InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V6] to bind to all interfaces or the IP address of a specific interface.

If an IP version 6 (IPv6) address is used, both IP version 6 (IPv6) and version 4 (IPv4) connections will be accepted. To restrict this to version 6 (IPv6) only, use dart-io.HttpServer.HttpServer-listenOn with a dart-io.ServerSocket configured for IP version 6 connections only.

If dart-io.HttpServer.bind.port has the value 0 an ephemeral port will be chosen by the system. The actual port used can be retrieved using the dart-io.HttpServer.bind.port getter.

The optional argument dart-io.HttpServer.bind.backlog can be used to specify the listen backlog for the underlying OS listen setup. If dart-io.HttpServer.bind.backlog has the value of 0 (the default) a reasonable value will be chosen by the system.

bindSecure.name: bindSecure
bindSecure.comment:
The dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.address can either be a dart-core.String or an dart-io.InternetAddress. If dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.address is a dart-core.String, dart-io.HttpServer.bind will perform a dart-io.InternetAddress.lookup and use the first value in the list. To listen on the loopback adapter, which will allow only incoming connections from the local host, use the value [InternetAddress.LOOPBACK_IP_V4] or [InternetAddress.LOOPBACK_IP_V6]. To allow for incoming connection from the network use either one of the values [InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V4] or [InternetAddress.ANY_IP_V6] to bind to all interfaces or the IP address of a specific interface.

If an IP version 6 (IPv6) address is used, both IP version 6 (IPv6) and version 4 (IPv4) connections will be accepted. To restrict this to version 6 (IPv6) only, use dart-io.HttpServer.HttpServer-listenOn with a dart-io.ServerSocket configured for IP version 6 connections only.

If dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.port has the value 0 an ephemeral port will be chosen by the system. The actual port used can be retrieved using the dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.port getter.

The optional argument dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.backlog can be used to specify the listen backlog for the underlying OS listen setup. If dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.backlog has the value of 0 (the default) a reasonable value will be chosen by the system.

The certificate with nickname or distinguished name (DN) dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.certificateName is looked up in the certificate database, and is used as the server certificate. If dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure.requestClientCertificate is true, the server will request clients to authenticate with a client certificate.

close.name: close
close.comment:
Permanently stops this dart-io.HttpServer from listening for new connections. This closes the dart-async.Stream of dart-io.HttpRequests with a done event. The returned future completes when the server is stopped. For a server started using dart-io.HttpServer.bind or dart-io.HttpServer.bindSecure this means that the port listened on no longer in use.

If dart-io.HttpServer.close.force is true, active connections will be closed immediately.

connectionsInfo.name: connectionsInfo
connectionsInfo.comment: Returns an dart-io.HttpConnectionsInfo object summarizing the number of current connections handled by the server.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.HttpServer.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

isBroadcast.name: isBroadcast
isBroadcast.comment: Reports whether this stream is a broadcast stream.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment:
Reports whether this stream contains any elements.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

first.name: first
first.comment:
Returns the first element of the stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this getter.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

Except for the type of the error, this method is equivalent to this.elementAt(0).

last.name: last
last.comment:
Returns the last element of the stream.

If an error event occurs before the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this stream is empty (a done event occurs before the first data event), the resulting future completes with a dart-core.StateError.

single.name: single
single.comment:
Returns the single element.

If an error event occurs before or after the first data event, the resulting future is completed with that error.

If this is empty or has more than one element throws a dart-core.StateError.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.HttpServer.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.HttpServer.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.HttpServer.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.HttpServer.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.HttpServer.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.HttpServer.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

asBroadcastStream.name: asBroadcastStream
asBroadcastStream.comment:
Returns a multi-subscription stream that produces the same events as this.

If this stream is already a broadcast stream, it is returned unmodified.

If this stream is single-subscription, return a new stream that allows multiple subscribers. It will subscribe to this stream when its first subscriber is added, and will stay subscribed until this stream ends, or a callback cancels the subscription.

If dart-io.HttpServer.asBroadcastStream.onListen is provided, it is called with a subscription-like object that represents the underlying subscription to this stream. It is possible to pause, resume or cancel the subscription during the call to dart-io.HttpServer.asBroadcastStream.onListen. It is not possible to change the event handlers, including using dart-async.StreamSubscription.asFuture.

If dart-io.HttpServer.asBroadcastStream.onCancel is provided, it is called in a similar way to dart-io.HttpServer.asBroadcastStream.onListen when the returned stream stops having listener. If it later gets a new listener, the dart-io.HttpServer.asBroadcastStream.onListen function is called again.

Use the callbacks, for example, for pausing the underlying subscription while having no subscribers to prevent losing events, or canceling the subscription when there are no listeners.

listen.name: listen
listen.comment:
Adds a subscription to this stream.

On each data event from this stream, the subscriber's dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onData handler is called. If dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onData is null, nothing happens.

On errors from this stream, the dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onError handler is given a object describing the error.

The dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). If dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onError accepts two arguments it is called with the stack trace (which could be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace). Otherwise it is called with just the error object.

If this stream closes, the dart-io.HttpServer.listen.onDone handler is called.

If dart-io.HttpServer.listen.cancelOnError is true, the subscription is ended when the first error is reported. The default is false.

where.name: where
where.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that discards some data events.

The new stream sends the same error and done events as this stream, but it only sends the data events that satisfy the dart-io.HttpServer.where.test.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

map.name: map
map.comment:
Creates a new stream that converts each element of this stream to a new value using the dart-io.HttpServer.map.convert function.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

asyncMap.name: asyncMap
asyncMap.comment:
Creates a new stream with each data event of this stream asynchronously mapped to a new event.

This acts like dart-io.HttpServer.map, except that dart-io.HttpServer.asyncMap.convert may return a dart-async.Future, and in that case, the stream waits for that future to complete before continuing with its result.

asyncExpand.name: asyncExpand
asyncExpand.comment:
Creates a new stream with the events of a stream per original event.

This acts like dart-io.HttpServer.expand, except that dart-io.HttpServer.asyncExpand.convert returns a dart-async.Stream instead of an dart-core.Iterable. The events of the returned stream becomes the events of the returned stream, in the order they are produced.

If dart-io.HttpServer.asyncExpand.convert returns null, no value is put on the output stream, just as if it returned an empty stream.

handleError.name: handleError
handleError.comment:
Creates a wrapper Stream that intercepts some errors from this stream.

If this stream sends an error that matches dart-io.HttpServer.handleError.test, then it is intercepted by the handle function.

The dart-io.HttpServer.handleError.onError callback must be of type void onError(error) or void onError(error, StackTrace stackTrace). Depending on the function type the the stream either invokes dart-io.HttpServer.handleError.onError with or without a stack trace. The stack trace argument might be null if the stream itself received an error without stack trace.

An asynchronous error e is matched by a test function if test(e) returns true. If dart-io.HttpServer.handleError.test is omitted, every error is considered matching.

If the error is intercepted, the handle function can decide what to do with it. It can throw if it wants to raise a new (or the same) error, or simply return to make the stream forget the error.

If you need to transform an error into a data event, use the more generic dart-io.HttpServer.transform to handle the event by writing a data event to the output sink

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

expand.name: expand
expand.comment:
Creates a new stream from this stream that converts each element into zero or more events.

Each incoming event is converted to an dart-core.Iterable of new events, and each of these new events are then sent by the returned stream in order.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

pipe.name: pipe
pipe.comment: Binds this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamConsumer.

transform.name: transform
transform.comment:
Chains this stream as the input of the provided dart-async.StreamTransformer.

Returns the result of streamTransformer.bind itself.

reduce.name: reduce
reduce.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.HttpServer.reduce.combine.

fold.name: fold
fold.comment: Reduces a sequence of values by repeatedly applying dart-io.HttpServer.fold.combine.

join.name: join
join.comment:
Collects string of data events' string representations.

If dart-io.HttpServer.join.separator is provided, it is inserted between any two elements.

Any error in the stream causes the future to complete with that error. Otherwise it completes with the collected string when the "done" event arrives.

contains.name: contains
contains.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpServer.contains.needle occurs in the elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Executes dart-io.HttpServer.forEach.action on each data event of the stream.

Completes the returned dart-async.Future when all events of the stream have been processed. Completes the future with an error if the stream has an error event, or if dart-io.HttpServer.forEach.action throws.

every.name: every
every.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpServer.every.test accepts all elements provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known. If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future will report that error.

any.name: any
any.comment:
Checks whether dart-io.HttpServer.any.test accepts any element provided by this stream.

Completes the dart-async.Future when the answer is known.

If this stream reports an error, the dart-async.Future reports that error.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been found.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after this element. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

toList.name: toList
toList.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.List.

toSet.name: toSet
toSet.comment: Collects the data of this stream in a dart-core.Set.

drain.name: drain
drain.comment:
Discards all data on the stream, but signals when it's done or an error occured.

When subscribing using dart-io.HttpServer.drain, cancelOnError will be true. This means that the future will complete with the first error on the stream and then cancel the subscription.

In case of a done event the future completes with the given dart-io.HttpServer.drain.futureValue.

take.name: take
take.comment:
Provides at most the first n values of this stream.

Forwards the first n data events of this stream, and all error events, to the returned stream, and ends with a done event.

If this stream produces fewer than dart-io.HttpServer.take.count values before it's done, so will the returned stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the first n elements have been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

takeWhile.name: takeWhile
takeWhile.comment:
Forwards data events while dart-io.HttpServer.takeWhile.test is successful.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream as long as dart-io.HttpServer.takeWhile.test returns true for the event data. The stream is done when either this stream is done, or when this stream first provides a value that dart-io.HttpServer.takeWhile.test doesn't accept.

Stops listening to the stream after the accepted elements.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skip.name: skip
skip.comment:
Skips the first dart-io.HttpServer.skip.count data events from this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

skipWhile.name: skipWhile
skipWhile.comment:
Skip data events from this stream while they are matched by dart-io.HttpServer.skipWhile.test.

Error and done events are provided by the returned stream unmodified.

Starting with the first data event where dart-io.HttpServer.skipWhile.test returns false for the event data, the returned stream will have the same events as this stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

distinct.name: distinct
distinct.comment:
Skips data events if they are equal to the previous data event.

The returned stream provides the same events as this stream, except that it never provides two consequtive data events that are equal.

Equality is determined by the provided dart-io.HttpServer.distinct.equals method. If that is omitted, the '==' operator on the last provided data element is used.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.

firstWhere.name: firstWhere
firstWhere.comment:
Finds the first element of this stream matching dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere.test.

Returns a future that is filled with the first element of this stream that dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere.test returns true for.

If no such element is found before this stream is done, and a dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere.defaultValue function is provided, the result of calling dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere.defaultValue becomes the value of the future.

Stops listening to the stream after the first matching element has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after the first element that matches the predicate. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error occurs, or if this stream ends without finding a match and with no dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere.defaultValue function provided, the future will receive an error.

lastWhere.name: lastWhere
lastWhere.comment:
Finds the last element in this stream matching dart-io.HttpServer.lastWhere.test.

As dart-io.HttpServer.firstWhere, except that the last matching element is found. That means that the result cannot be provided before this stream is done.

singleWhere.name: singleWhere
singleWhere.comment:
Finds the single element in this stream matching dart-io.HttpServer.singleWhere.test.

Like lastMatch, except that it is an error if more than one matching element occurs in the stream.

elementAt.name: elementAt
elementAt.comment:
Returns the value of the dart-io.HttpServer.elementAt.indexth data event of this stream.

Stops listening to the stream after the dart-io.HttpServer.elementAt.indexth data event has been received.

Internally the method cancels its subscription after these elements. This means that single-subscription (non-broadcast) streams are closed and cannot be reused after a call to this method.

If an error event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with this error.

If a done event occurs before the value is found, the future completes with a dart-core.RangeError.

timeout.name: timeout
timeout.comment:
Creates a new stream with the same events as this stream.

Whenever more than dart-io.HttpServer.timeout.timeLimit passes between two events from this stream, the dart-io.HttpServer.timeout.onTimeout function is called.

The countdown doesn't start until the returned stream is listened to. The countdown is reset every time an event is forwarded from this stream, or when the stream is paused and resumed.

The dart-io.HttpServer.timeout.onTimeout function is called with one argument: an dart-async.EventSink that allows putting events into the returned stream. This EventSink is only valid during the call to onTimeout.

If onTimeout is omitted, a timeout will just put a dart-async.TimeoutException into the error channel of the returned stream.

The returned stream is not a broadcast stream, even if this stream is.
